Award.AwardTitle: Knots in Washington: Conferences on Knot Theory and its Ramifications 2008-2010
Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0817858<br/>Principal Investigator: Jozef H. Przytycki, Yongwu Rong,<br/>Alexander N. Shumakovitch, Hao Wu<br/><br/>A series of conferences devoted to knot theory and its<br/>ramifications will be held in 2008-2010, continuing the "Knots in<br/>Washington" conferences held every semester in the greater<br/>Washington, D.C. area since fall 1995. Plenary talks will<br/>survey the state of knowledge in areas such as Khovanov homology,<br/>Heegard Floer homology, and categorification of existing<br/>invariants such as skein modules. Contributed talks and periods<br/>devoted to interaction among participants provide opportunities<br/>for graduate students and recent PhDs to be a part of "Knots in<br/>Washington," and the organizers encourage students and junior<br/>researchers to attend these meetings.<br/><br/>Low dimensional topology studies shapes of three and four<br/>dimensional spaces. These dimensions are of particular interest<br/>to us because they are the dimensions of our space and our<br/>space-time. Knot theory is a subfield of low dimensional<br/>topology, which studies the knottedness in our space. One of the<br/>main goals of knot theory is to distinguish knotted objects. This<br/>is often done by means of the so called "knot invariants,"<br/>functions that replace geometric objects, such as knots, with<br/>those that are easier to compare. Over the past two decades,<br/>there have been a flourish of new invariants in low dimensional<br/>topology, boosted by ideas from gauge theory, quantum algebras,<br/>and mathematical physics. The purpose of the "Knots in<br/>Washington Conferences" is to bring together the researchers of<br/>the field, including established mathematicians as well as<br/>graduate students and recent PhDs, to discuss the state of the<br/>art of the subject. The conference web page is<br/>http://home.gwu.edu/~przytyck/knots/index.html.<br/><br/><br/>
